Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Virtual Reality vs. Noninteractive Visual Distraction in Pediatric Orthopaedic Procedures

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to one of three groups

Participants.evidence: Conducted at a single urban tertiary institution, the study included children scheduled for cast or percutaneous pin removal.

Intervention.evidence: VR gaming simulation versus noninteractive visual distraction (VR goggles or tablet video)

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial assessed the effectiveness of virtual reality (VR) gaming simulation versus noninteractive visual distraction

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcomes were preprocedure-to-maximum heart rate increase and preprocedure to postprocedure visual analog scale (VAS) scores for pain and anxiety.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed.

Result_Outcome.evidence: largest mean difference -6 bpm [95% CI -16 to 3]; p = 0.36

Trial_Registration.evidence: Trial registration and funding details were not provided.

Funding.evidence: Trial registration and funding details were not provided.
